page.title: 04The Brecon Canal
page.content: The Monmouthshire and Brecon canal started work in 1799 and was completed in 1812. It is 33.5 miles long and has 6 locks. It has a tunnel called the Ashford tunnel and is 370 yards long. The canal was built because the roads could not cope with iron from the industrial towns.When the canal opened , the price of a 100 weight of coal went down from 6 new pence to 4 new pence because of the cheaper transport offered by the canal. The canal along its whole length runs between the 400 and 500 foot mark above sea level and along its whole length, it only rises 84 feet by the help of 6 locks. The canal starts at the public warf in Brecon and ends at the 5 locks Cwmbran. Until recently the canal has been in a bad state, but now repairs are under way to return the it to its former glory.
